title: CROWler Configuration Schema
description: This is the configuration schema for the CROWler. This schema describes all the sections of the config.yaml configuration file and provides info on configuring a fleet of CROWler's Engines, VDIs, APIs and how they should work. Keep in mind that the 'remote' property should be used on its own, and the 'database', 'crawler', 'api', 'selenium', 'network_info' properties should be used together.

version.title: CROWler Configuration version
version.description: This is the version of the CROWler configuration. This is for you to version your work.

author.title: CROWler Configuration author
author.description: This is the author of the CROWler configuration.

created_at.title: CROWler Configuration creation date
created_at.description: This is the date when the CROWler configuration was created.

remote.title: Remote Configuration
remote.description: This is the remote configuration section to tell the CROWler's Engine that the actual config.yaml configuration has to be fetched remotely from a distribution server. If you use this section, then do not populate the other configuration sections as they will be ignored. The CROWler will fetch its configuration from the remote server and use it to start the engine.

host.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Host
host.description: This is the host that the CROWler will use to fetch its configuration.

path.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Path
path.description: This is the path that the CROWler will use to fetch its configuration.

port.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Port
port.description: This is the port that the CROWler will use to fetch its configuration.

region.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Region
region.description: This is the region that the CROWler will use to fetch its configuration. For example in case the distribution server is on an AWS S3 bucket, you can specify the region here.

token.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Token
token.description: This is the token that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to fetch its configuration.

secret.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Secret
secret.description: This is the secret that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to fetch its configuration.

timeout.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the CROWler to fetch its configuration.

type.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server Type
type.description: This is the type of the distribution server that the CROWler will use to fetch its configuration. For example, s3 or http.

sslmode.title: CROWler Configuration Distribution Server SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to fetch its configuration.

database.title: CROWler DB Configuration CDBI
database.description: This is the database configuration section, it's used to tell the CROWler how to connect to the database to store collected data, which type of database we use and other options to optimize the database for a specific use case.

type.title: CROWler DB Type
type.description: This is the type of the database that the CROWler will use to store data. For example, postgres.

host.title: CROWler DB Host
host.description: This is the host that the CROWler will use to connect to the database.

port.title: CROWler DB Port
port.description: This is the port that the CROWler will use to connect to the database.

user.title: CROWler DB User
user.description: This is the user that the CROWler will use to connect to the database.

dbname.title: CROWler DB Name
dbname.description: This is the name of the database that the CROWler will use to store data.

retry_time.title: CROWler DB Retry Time
retry_time.description: This is the time in seconds that the CROWler will wait before retrying a database connection.

ping_time.title: CROWler DB Ping Time
ping_time.description: This is the time in seconds that the CROWler will wait before pinging the database to check if it is still alive.

sslmode.title: CROWler DB SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode that the CROWler will use to connect to the database. Use 'enable' to enable the ssl mode connection to the DB. (default is 'disable').

optimize_for.title: CROWler DB Optimize For
optimize_for.description: This option allows the user to optimize the database for a specific use case. For example, if the user is doing more write operations than query, then use the value 'write'. If the user is doing more query operations than write, then use the value 'query'. If unsure leave it empty.

max_conns.title: CROWler DB Max Connections
max_conns.description: This is the maximum number of connections that the CROWler will use to connect to the database.

max_idle_conns.title: CROWler DB Max Idle Connections
max_idle_conns.description: This is the maximum number of idle connections that the CROWler will use to connect to the database. Suggestion, keep the number of idle connections to 25% / 30% of the max connections, unless you have plenty of resources.

crawler.title: CROWler Engine's crawling Configuration CEI
crawler.description: This is the crawler (CROWler Engine) configuration section, it's used to tell the CROWler's engine how to behave. It is the configuration for the CROWler engine that the CROWler will use to crawl websites, spin workers and configure it's internal Control API.

query_timer.title: CROWler Engine Query Timer
query_timer.description: This is the query timer for the CROWler Engine. It is the time in seconds that the CROWler Engine will wait before querying the database for new sources to crawl. (default every 30 seconds)

workers.title: CROWler Engine Workers
workers.description: This is the number of workers that the CROWler Engine will use to crawl websites. Minimum number is 3 per each Source if you have network discovery enabled or 1 per each source if you are doing crawling only. Increase the number of workers to scale up the CROWler engine vertically.

engine.title: CROWler Engine Configuration for each CROWler Engine instance
engine.description: This is the configuration for each CROWler Engine instance. This section is used to customize the CROWler Engine behavior for each instance.

name.title: CROWler Engine Instance Name
name.description: This is the name of the CROWler Engine instance. Normally it's either the hostname or the container name in which the engine is running.

query_timer.title: CROWler Engine Query Timer
query_timer.description: This is the query timer for the CROWler Engine. It is the time in seconds that the CROWler Engine will wait before querying the database for new sources to crawl.

source_priority.title: Configure the priority that this instance will use to filter the sources
source_priority.description: This is a list of priorities that CROWler Engine will use to filter the sources. For example 'high' to filter for high priority, 'medium,low' to pick only medium and low priority sources, 'my_priority' to pick the source with your specific custom priority.

vdi_name.title: CROWler Engine VDI Name
vdi_name.description: Specify a list of VDIs that this instance of the Engine will use to crawl sources that have been picked by it.

platform.title: CROWler Engine Platform
platform.description: This is the platform that the CROWler Engine will use to crawl websites. For example, 'desktop' or 'mobile' (mobile is experimental!).

browser_platform.title: CROWler Engine Browser Platform
browser_platform.description: This is the browser platform id. The CROWler Engine will use it to select the user-agent string to use to configure the session. For example, 'darwin', 'window', 'random' or 'linux'.

interval.title: CROWler Engine Page Rendering Interval
interval.description: This is the interval at which the CROWler Engine will crawl websites. It is the part of the HBS, values are in seconds, e.g. '3' means 3 seconds. For the interval you can also use the CROWler exprterpreter to generate delay values at runtime, e.g., 'random(1, 3)' or 'random(random(1,3), random(5,8))'.

timeout.title: CROWler Engine Page Fetching Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout (in seconds) for the CROWler Engine. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler Engine will wait for a website to respond.

crawling_interval.title: CROWler Engine Crawling Interval
crawling_interval.description: This is the interval at which the CROWler Engine will crawl websites. It is the interval at which the CROWler will crawl each given source. The default value is '3 days', e.g. '1 day' means crawl each source every day.

crawling_if_error.title: CROWler Engine Crawling If Error
crawling_if_error.description: This is re-crawling-after in case of error during the original crawling. Default is 'retry after 15 minutes'. For example, '1 hour' means re-crawl after 1 hour.

crawling_if_ok.title: CROWler Engine Crawling If OK
crawling_if_ok.description: This is re-crawling-after in case of success during the original crawling. Default is 'retry after 3 days'. For example, '1 hour' means re-crawl after 1 hour.

processing_timeout.title: CROWler Engine Processing Timeout
processing_timeout.description: This is the timeout for the CROWler Engine to process a website. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for a website to be processed. If a source stays in processing for more than this time, the CROWler will re-schedule it for a new processing.

maintenance.title: CROWler Engine DB Maintenance Interval
maintenance.description: This is the DB maintenance interval (in seconds) for the CROWler Engine. It is the interval at which the CROWler will perform automatic maintenance tasks, a value of 0 means NO automatic DB maintenance.

source_screenshot.title: CROWler Engine Source Screenshot
source_screenshot.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to take a screenshot of the source website. This is useful for debugging purposes.

full_site_screenshot.title: CROWler Engine Full Site Screenshots
full_site_screenshot.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to take a screenshot of the full website. This is useful for debugging purposes.

max_depth.title: CROWler Engine Crawling Maximum Depth
max_depth.description: This is the maximum depth that the CROWler Engine will crawl websites.

max_links.title: CROWler Engine Crawling Maximum Number of Links
max_links.description: This is the maximum number of links that the CROWler Engine will crawl per each Source. If zero, no limit.

max_sources.title: CROWler Engine Maximum Sources
max_sources.description: This is the maximum number of sources that a single instance of the CROWler's engine will fetch atomically and atomically to enqueue in the jobs-queue and crawl.

initial_ramp_up.title: CROWler Engine Initial Ramp Up
initial_ramp_up.description: This is the initial ramp up for the CROWler Engine. It is the time in seconds that the CROWler Engine will wait in between starting collecting data for each source in a new batch (at the beginning of a new collection). Valid values are < 0 for automatic ramp-up, 0 for no ramp-up, > 0 for manual ramp-up. A ramp-up can be useful to help proxies to 'warm up'.

delay.title: CROWler Engine Delay Between Page's Fetching Requests
delay.description: This is the delay between requests that the CROWler Engine will use to crawl websites. It is the delay between requests that the CROWler will use as part of the HBS. For delay you can also use the CROWler exprterpreter to generate delay values at runtime, e.g., 'random(1, 3)' or 'random(random(1,3), random(5,8))'.

browsing_mode.title: CROWler Engine Browsing Mode
browsing_mode.description:
This is the 'default' browsing mode that the CROWler Engine will use to crawl websites. For example, recursive, human, or fuzzing.
- default or empty string means use recursive mode.
- recursive means the CROWler will crawl websites in a recursive way.
- right_click_recursive means the CROWler will crawl websites in a right-click recursive way.
- human means the CROWler will crawl websites in a human way.
- fuzzing means the CROWler will crawl websites by fuzzing URL and Query Parameters (this also requires crawling rules!).

max_retries.title: CROWler Engine Maximum Retries for a Website
max_retries.description: This is the maximum number of times that the CROWler Engine will retry a request to a website. If the CROWler is unable to fetch a website after this number of retries, it will move on to the next website.

max_requests.title: CROWler Engine Maximum Requests for a Website
max_requests.description: This is the maximum number of requests that the CROWler will send to a website. If the CROWler sends this number of requests to a website and is unable to fetch the website, it will move on to the next website. A value of 0 means no limit.

change_useragent.title: CROWler Engine Change UserAgent at every new request
change_useragent.description: This is the policy that the CROWler Engine will use to change the User-Agent at every new request. For example, 'always' means the CROWler will change the User-Agent on every request, 'never' means the CROWler will never change the User-Agent, 'on_start' means the CROWler will change the User-Agent only at the beginning of a crawling process.

force_sec_fetch_site_same_origin.title: CRWOler engine forces sec-fetch-site same-origin
force_sec_fetch_site_same_origin.description: This is a technique that is required for websites that requires sec-fetch-site same-origin for all pages except the home page. Some website uses this technique to block crawlers from crawl specific URLs. The CROWler can go around it when the user enable this check.

reset_cookies_policy.title: CROWler Engine Reset Cookies Policy
reset_cookies_policy.description: This is the policy that the CROWler Engine will use to reset cookies. For example, 'always' means the CROWler will reset cookies on every request and when done, 'never' means the CROWler will never reset cookies, 'on_start' means the CROWler will reset cookies only at the beginning of a crawling process.

no_third_party_cookies.title: CROWler Engine No Third Party Cookies
no_third_party_cookies.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler Engine to not allow third-party cookies. This is useful for privacy reasons.

request_images.title: CROWler Engine Request Images
request_images.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to request images from a website. This can be useful to reduce bandwidth usage (if set to false) and speed up the crawling process. Images are requested by default.

request_css.title: CROWler Engine Request CSS
request_css.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to request CSS from a website. This can be useful to reduce bandwidth usage (if set to false) and speed up the crawling process. CSS are requested by default.

request_scripts.title: CROWler Engine Request Scripts
request_scripts.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to request scripts from a website. This can be useful to reduce bandwidth usage (if set to false) and speed up the crawling process, but can break a site functioning (so make sure you know what you're doing when you set it to false). Scripts are requested by default.

request_plugins.title: CROWler Engine Request Plugins
request_plugins.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to request plugins from a website. This can be useful to reduce bandwidth usage (if set to false) and speed up the crawling process, but can break a site functioning (so make sure you know what you're doing when you set it to false). Plugins are requested by default.

request_frames.title: CROWler Engine Request Frames
request_frames.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to request frames from a website. This can be useful to reduce bandwidth usage (if set to false) and speed up the crawling process, but can break a site functioning (so make sure you know what you're doing when you set it to false). Frames are requested by default.

prevent_duplicate_urls.title: CROWler Engine Prevent Duplicate URLs
prevent_duplicate_urls.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to prevent crawling of duplicate URLs. This can be useful to reduce redundant work and save resources. It's a tag that is not reliable 100%, but it can help to reduce the number of duplicate URLs that the CROWler will crawl.

collect_html.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's HTML
collect_html.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the HTML of a website. This is also useful for debugging purposes. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source.

collect_images.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Images
collect_images.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect images from a website. This is also useful for debugging purposes. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source

collect_files.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Files
collect_files.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect files from a website. This is also useful for debugging purposes. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source

collect_content.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Content (as text)
collect_content.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the text content of a website. This is also useful for AI datasets creation and knowledge bases. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source

collect_keywords.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Keywords
collect_keywords.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the keywords of a website. This is also useful for AI datasets creation and knowledge bases. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source. Keywords and metadata are used in searches, so we recommend enabling this option.

collect_metatags.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Metatags
collect_metatags.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the metatags of a website. This is useful for AI datasets creation and knowledge bases. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source. Keywords and metadata are used in searches, so we recommend enabling this option.

collect_performance.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Performance
collect_performance.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the performance of each page of a website.

collect_events.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Events
collect_events.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the events of a website. This is useful for Cybersecurity applications, given it collects all page's events, included JavaScript events like calling-back home etc. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source.

collect_xhr.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's XHR
collect_xhr.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the XHR of a website. This is useful for Cybersecurity applications, given it collects all page's XHR requests. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source.

filter_xhr.title: CROWler Engine Filter Page's XHR
filter_xhr.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to filter the XHR of a website. This is useful for Cybersecurity applications, given it filters all page's XHR requests. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source.

collect_links.title: CROWler Engine Collect Page's Links
collect_links.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect the links of a website. This is useful for AI datasets creation and knowledge bases. This collection is automatic and for each page of a Source.

create_event_when_done.title: CROWler Engine Create Event When Done
create_event_when_done.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to create an event when the crawling process is done. The event will be created with the event type `crawl_completed`. This is useful for monitoring purposes.

control.title: CROWler Engine (internal) Control API Configuration
control.description: This is the CROWler's Control API configuration. The Control API is an internal management API that resides within the CROWler Engine. Its primary purpose is to allow internal tools, like health checks, to monitor and manage the operational status of the CROWler Engine (e.g., starting, stopping, or checking the status of crawls). It is used to control and manage engine-level operations. Important: The Control API has nothing to do with the General API (configured using the api section). The General API is an external-facing interface, exposed to interact with The CROWler to make data requests or post new sources. This section specifically configures the Control API, which operates within the CROWler Engine itself. Unlike the General API, which is designed for external interactions, the Control API is part of the CROWler’s Engine internal management system, and is not an external service.

host.title: CROWler Engine Control API Host
host.description: This is the host that the CROWler will use to allow connections to the control API.

port.title: CROWler Engine Control API Port
port.description: This is the port that the CROWler will use to allow connections to the control API.

timeout.title: CROWler Engine Control API Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout (in seconds) for the control API. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the control API to respond.

sslmode.title: CROWler Engine Control API SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode switch for the control API. Use 'enable' to make the control API use HTTPS.

cert_file.title: CROWler Engine Control API Certificate File
cert_file.description: This is the certificate file for the Control API HTTPS protocol.

key_file.title: CROWler Engine Control API Key File
key_file.description: This is the full path to the key file for the Control API HTTPS certificates.

rate_limit.title: CROWler Engine Control API Requests Rate Limit
rate_limit.description: This is the rate limit for the control API. It is the maximum number of requests that the CROWler Engine will accept per second. You can use the ExprTerpreter language to set the rate limit. The format of this parameter is 'query_per_second, total_query' (for example: '100,100').

readheader_timeout.title: CROWler Engine Control API Readheader Timeout
readheader_timeout.description: This is the readheader timeout (in seconds) for the Control API. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the control API to respond.

write_timeout.title: CROWler Engine Control API Write Timeout
write_timeout.description: This is the write timeout (in seconds) for the Control API. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the control API to respond.

api.title: CROWler General/Search API Configuration
api.description: This is the General/Search API configuration section, it's used to configure the General/Search API and it has no effect on the CROWler's engine, nor it has anything to do with the Engine's Control API. It is the configuration for the API that the CROWler will use to communicate with the outside world, to allow users to make queries, post Sources, check the status of the crawling activities etc.

host.title: CROWler General/Search API Host
host.description: This is the host that the API will use to communicate with the outside world. Use 0.0.0.0 to make the API accessible from any IP address.

port.title: CROWler General/Search API Port
port.description: This is the port that the API will use to communicate with the outside world.

timeout.title: CROWler General/Search API Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the API. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the API to respond.

content_search.title: CROWler General/Search API Content Search
content_search.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to search also in the text content field of a web object. This is useful for searching for every possible details of a web object, however will reduce performance quite a bit.

return_content.title: CROWler General/Search API Return Content
return_content.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to return the web object's text content of a page in the search results. To improve performance, you can disable this option.

sslmode.title: CROWler General/Search API SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode switch for the API. Use 'enable' to make the API use HTTPS.

cert_file.title: CROWler General/Search API Certificate File
cert_file.description: This is the certificate file for the General/Search API HTTPS protocol.

key_file.title: CROWler General/Search API Key File
key_file.description: This is the key file for the General/Search API HTTPS certificates.

rate_limit.title: CROWler General/Search API Requests Rate Limit
rate_limit.description: This is the rate limit for the General/Search API. It is the maximum number of requests that the CROWler General API will accept per second. You can use the ExprTerpreter language to set the rate limit.

readheader_timeout.title: CROWler General/Search API Readheader Timeout
readheader_timeout.description: This is the readheader timeout (in seconds) for the General/Search API. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the General/Search API to respond.

write_timeout.title: CROWler Engine General/Search API Write Timeout
write_timeout.description: This is the write timeout (in seconds) for the General/Search API. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the control API to respond.

enable_console.title: CROWler General/Search API Enable Admin Console
enable_console.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler General API to enable the 'admin console' via the API. In other words, you'll get more endpoints to manage the CROWler via the General API instead of having to use local commands to do admin tasks.

return_404.title: CROWler General/Search API Return 404
return_404.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to return 404 status code if a query has no results. This is mostly a secure measure to avoid leaking information about the CROWler's internal structure. If you are not exposing the General API to the public, you can disable this option.

selenium.title: CROWler VDI access Configuration
selenium.description: This is the VDI configuration section, it's used to configure the VDI and tell the CROWler's Engine how to connect to it. It is the configuration for all the tools in the VDI image (for ex. selenium driver, Rbee etc.), to scale the CROWler web crawling capabilities, you can add multiple VDIs in an array format.

name.title: CROWler VDI Name
name.description: This is the name of the VDI image. This is not a network name, so you can pick whatever makes sense for your business logic. This name can be used in a Source Configuration, to ensure the CROWler will use that specific VDI image to crawl the website.

location.title: CROWler VDI Location
location.description: This is the location of the VDI image.

language.title: CROWler VDI Language
language.description: This is the language oto set the VDI image to.

path.title: CROWler Selenium Path
path.description: This is the path to the selenium driver (IF LOCAL). It is the path to the selenium driver that the CROWler will use to crawl websites. (deprecated)

driver_path.title: CROWler Selenium Driver Path
driver_path.description: This is the path to the selenium driver (IF REMOTE). It is the path to the selenium driver that the CROWler will use to crawl websites. (deprecated)

use_service.title: CROWler VDI Use Service (deprecated)
use_service.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to access Selenium as service. (deprecated)

type.title: CROWler VDI Browser Type
type.description: This is the type of web browser the CROWler will use to crawl websites. For example, chrome or firefox (normally a VDI image has only one web Browser to reduce space).

port.title: CROWler VDI Port
port.description: This is the VDI's API port.

host.title: CROWler VDI Host
host.description: This is the VDI host name or IP that the CROWler will use to connect to the VDI. It is the host that will be used to fetch web pages and that runs Selenium, RBee etc. For example, localhost. This is also the recommended way to use and connect to a VDI (in other words, don't try to run selenium, Rbee etc. locally, use a container for the VDI).

headless.title: CROWler VDI Headless Mode
headless.description: This is a flag that tells the VDI to run in headless mode. This is useful for running the selenium driver in a headless environment. It's generally NOT recommended to enable headless mode. (don't use headless unless you know what you're doing, headless browsing is mostly blocked these days!)

sslmode.title: CROWler VDI SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode. If set to `enable` then the CROWler Engine will try to connect to the VDI using HTTPS. Make sure the VDI is configured to accept HTTPS connections.

download_path.title: CROWler VDI Downloaded files Path
download_path.description: This is the temporary download path for the VDI. It is the local path where the VDI will download files. This is useful for downloading files from websites (like pdf or zip etc.). The CROWler will use this path to temporarily store the downloaded files (before moving them to the storage files area).

proxy_url.title: CROWler VDI Proxy Configuration
proxy_url.description: This is the proxy configuration for the VDI. It is the proxy that the VDI will use to connect to the internet. This is useful for bypassing firewalls or accessing websites that are blocked in your country.

sys_manager.title: CROWler VDI System Manager
sys_manager.description: This configures the VDI System Manager API. It is the API that the CROWler will use to manage the VDI. This is used to configure system-wide proxy settings, manage the VDI's resources, and perform other system-level tasks.

port.title: CROWler VDI System Manager Port
port.description: This is the port that the VDI System Manager will use to communicate with the outside world.

timeout.title: CROWler VDI System Manager Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the VDI System Manager. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the VDI System Manager to respond.

sslmode.title: CROWler VDI System Manager SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode switch for the VDI System Manager. Use 'enable' to make the VDI System Manager use HTTPS.

enabled.title: CROWler Prometheus Exporter Enabled
enabled.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to enable the Prometheus Exporter. The Prometheus Exporter is a tool that allows you to monitor the CROWler's performance and health using Prometheus.

port.title: CROWler Prometheus Exporter Port
port.description: This is the Prometheus Exporter Host Port that each CROWler engines will use to send their metrics.

host.title: CROWler Prometheus Exporter Host
host.description: This is the Prometheus Exporter host that each CROWler engines will use to send their metrics.

events.title: CROWler Events Manager Configuration (CEMI)
events.description: This is the Events Manager configuration section, it is used to configure the Events Manager

host.title: CROWler Events Manager Host
host.description: This is the host that the Events Manager will use to communicate with the outside world.

port.title: CROWler Events Manager Port
port.description: This is the port that the Events Manager will use to communicate with the outside world.

timeout.title: CROWler Events Manager Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the Events Manager. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the Events Manager to respond.

sslmode.title: CROWler Events Manager SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode switch for the Events Manager. Use 'enable' to make the Events Manager use HTTPS.

cert_file.title: CROWler Events Manager Certificate File
cert_file.description: This is the certificate file for the Events Manager HTTPS protocol.

key_file.title: CROWler Events Manager Key File
key_file.description: This is the key file for the Events Manager HTTPS certificates.

rate_limit.title: CROWler Events Manager Requests Rate Limit
rate_limit.description: This is the rate limit for the Events Manager. It is the maximum number of requests that the CROWler Events Manager will accept per second. You can use the ExprTerpreter language to set the rate limit.

readheader_timeout.title: CROWler Events Manager Readheader Timeout
readheader_timeout.description: This is the readheader timeout (in seconds) for the Events Manager. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the Events Manager to respond.

write_timeout.title: CROWler Events Manager Write Timeout
write_timeout.description: This is the write timeout (in seconds) for the Events Manager. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the Events Manager to respond.

automatic_events_removal.title: CROWler Events Manager Automatic Events Removal
automatic_events_removal.description: This field help automating events removal from the database. It supports one fo the following values: always, failed, success, never or empty string. If set to always it means remove the event always, if set to on_failure it means remove the event only if the handling fails, if set to on_success it means remove the event only if the handling is successful, if set to never it means never remove the event, if set to empty string it means the default behavior (always).

image_storage.title: CROWler Images Storage access Configuration
image_storage.description: This is the Image Storage configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine how and where to store collected images.

host.title: CROWler Image Storage Host
host.description: This is the remote host for the image storage request.

path.title: CROWler Image Storage Path
path.description: This is the path to the image storage. It is the path to the storage that the CROWler will use to store images. if the image storage is local, this is the path to the local directory where the images will be stored. If the image storage is remote, this is the path to the remote storage where the images will be stored.

port.title: CROWler Image Storage Host Port
port.description: This is the remote port for the image storage request.

region.title: CROWler Image Storage Region
region.description: This is the region for the image storage request (for example for AWS s3 buckets).

token.title: CROWler Image Storage Token
token.description: This is the token for the image storage request for remote storage.

secret.title: CROWler Image Storage Secret
secret.description: This is the secret for the image storage request for remote storage.

timeout.title: CROWler Image Storage Timeout
timeout.description: This is the remote request timeout in seconds.

type.title: CROWler Image Storage Type
type.description: This is the type of storage that the CROWler will use to store images. For example, s3, http or local (local is the default type).

sslmode.title: CROWler Image Storage SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the ssl mode for the image storage request for remote storage. Use enable to force https over http.

file_storage.title: CROWler general Files Storage access Configuration
file_storage.description: This is the File Storage configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine how and where to store collected files.

host.title: CROWler File Storage Host
host.description: This is the remote host for the file storage request.

path.title: CROWler File Storage Path
path.description: This is the path to the file storage. It is the path to the storage that the CROWler will use to store files. if the file storage is local, this is the path to the local directory where the files will be stored. If the file storage is remote, this is the path to the remote storage where the files will be stored.

port.title: CROWler File Storage Host Port
port.description: This is the remote port for the file storage request.

region.title: CROWler File Storage Region
region.description: This is the region for the file storage request (for example for AWS s3 buckets).

token.title: CROWler File Storage Token
token.description: This is the token for the file storage request for remote storage.

secret.title: CROWler File Storage Secret
secret.description: This is the secret for the file storage request for remote storage.

timeout.title: CROWler File Storage Timeout
timeout.description: This is the remote request timeout in seconds.

type.title: CROWler File Storage Type
type.description: This is the type of storage that the CROWler will use to store files. For example, s3, http or local (local is the default type).

sslmode.title: CROWler File Storage SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the ssl mode for the file storage request for remote storage. Use enable to force https over http.

http_headers.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Configuration
http_headers.description: This is the HTTP Headers collection configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine to collect HTTP headers and how when making requests to websites.

enabled.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Enabled
enabled.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to collect HTTP headers. This is useful for detecting the headers of a website.

timeout.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the HTTP headers collection. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the HTTP headers to respond.

follow_redirects.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Follow Redirects
follow_redirects.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to follow redirects when collecting HTTP headers. This is useful for detecting the headers of a website.

ssl_discovery.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection SSL Discovery
ssl_discovery.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to discover SSL certificates when collecting HTTP headers. This is useful for detecting the headers of a website.

proxies.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Proxies
proxies.description: This is the list of proxies that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers.

items.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Proxies Items

host.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Proxy Host
host.description: This is the proxy host that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers. It is the proxy host that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers.

port.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Proxy Port
port.description: This is the proxy port that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers. It is the proxy port that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers.

username.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Proxy Username
username.description: This is the proxy username that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers. It is the proxy username that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers.

password.title: CROWler HTTP Headers collection Proxy Password
password.description: This is the proxy password that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers. It is the proxy password that the CROWler will use to collect HTTP headers.

network_info.title: CROWler Network Information collection Configuration
network_info.description: This is the network information collection configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine how and what network information we want to collect for each discovered entity within the crawling of a Source. This section is also used to tell the CROWler if we want to detect network vulnerabilities, open ports, etc. Collect Whois information, DNS information, and more.

dns.title: CROWler Network Information collection DNS Configuration
dns.description: This is the configuration for the DNS data collection. It is the configuration for the DNS data collection that the CROWler will use to detect the IP address of a domain, subdomains etc.

enabled.title: CROWler Network Information collection DNS Enabled
enabled.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use DNS techniques. This is useful for detecting the IP address of a domain.

timeout.title: CROWler Network Information collection DNS Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the DNS database. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the DNS database to respond.

rate_limit.title: CROWler Network Information collection DNS Rate Limit
rate_limit.description: This is the rate limit for the DNS database. It is the maximum number of requests that the CROWler will send to the DNS database per second. You can use the ExprTerpreter language to set the rate limit.

whois.title: CROWler Network Information collection Whois Configuration
whois.description: This is the configuration for the whois data collection. It is the configuration for the whois data collection that the CROWler will use to detect the owner of a domain.

enabled.title: CROWler Network Information collection Whois Enabled
enabled.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use whois techniques. This is useful for detecting the owner of a domain.

timeout.title: CROWler Network Information collection Whois Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the whois database. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the whois database to respond.

rate_limit.title: CROWler Network Information collection Whois Rate Limit
rate_limit.description: This is the rate limit for the whois database. It is the maximum number of requests that the CROWler will send to the whois database per second. You can use the ExprTerpreter language to set the rate limit.

netlookup.title: CROWler Network Information collection Netlookup Configuration
netlookup.description: This is the configuration for the netlookup data collection. It is the configuration for the netlookup data collection that the CROWler will use to detect the network information of a host.

enabled.title: CROWler Network Information collection Netlookup Enabled
enabled.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use netlookup techniques. This is useful for detecting the network information of a host.

timeout.title: CROWler Network Information collection Netlookup Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the netlookup database. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the netlookup database to respond.

rate_limit.title: CROWler Network Information collection Netlookup Rate Limit
rate_limit.description: This is the rate limit for the netlookup database. It is the maximum number of requests that the CROWler will send to the netlookup database per second. You can use the ExprTerpreter language to set the rate limit.

geo_localization.title: CROWler Network Information collection Geolocation Configuration
geo_localization.description: This is the configuration for the geolocation data collection. It is the configuration for the geolocation data collection that the CROWler will use to detect the location of a host.

enabled.title: CROWler Network Information collection Geolocation Enabled
enabled.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use geolocation techniques. This is useful for detecting the location of a host.

path.title: CROWler Network Information collection Geolocation Path
path.description: This is the path to the geolocation database. It is the path to the database that the CROWler will use to determine the location of a host.

type.title: CROWler Network Information collection Geolocation Type
type.description: This is the type of geolocation database that the CROWler will use. It is the type of database that the CROWler will use to determine the location of a host. For example maxmind or ip2location

timeout.title: CROWler Network Information collection Geolocation Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the geolocation database. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for the geolocation database to respond.

api_key.title: CROWler Network Information collection Geolocation API Key
api_key.description: This is the API key for the geolocation database. It is the API key that the CROWler will use to connect to the geolocation database.

sslmode.title: CROWler Network Information collection Geolocation SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode that the CROWler will use to connect to the geolocation database.

service_scout.title: Service Scout Configuration
service_scout.description: This is the configuration for the service scout data collection. It is the configuration for the service scout data collection that the CROWler will use to detect services that are running on a host, network vulnerabilities, network software versions etc.

enabled.title: Service Enabled
enabled.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use service scanning techniques. This is useful for detecting services that are running on a host.

timeout.title: Service Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout for the scan. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for a host to respond to a scan.

idle_scan.title: Service Idle Scan Config
idle_scan.description: This is the configuration for the idle scan.

ping_scan.title: Ping Scan
ping_scan.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use ping scanning techniques. This is useful for detecting hosts that are alive.

connect_scan.title: Connect Scan
connect_scan.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use connect scanning techniques. This is useful for detecting services that are running on a host.

syn_scan.title: SYN Scan
syn_scan.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use SYN scanning techniques. This is useful for detecting services that are running on a host.

udp_scan.title: UDP Scan
udp_scan.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use UDP scanning techniques. This is useful for detecting services that are running on a host.

no_dns_resolution.title: No DNS Resolution
no_dns_resolution.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler not to resolve hostnames to IP addresses. This is useful for avoiding detection by intrusion detection systems.

service_detection.title: Service Detection
service_detection.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use service detection techniques. This is useful for detecting services that are running on a host.

service_db.title: Service DB file
service_db.description: This is the service detection database.

os_finger_print.title: OS Fingerprinting
os_finger_print.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use OS fingerprinting techniques. This is useful for detecting the operating system that is running on a host.

aggressive_scan.title: Aggressive Scan
aggressive_scan.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use aggressive scanning techniques. This is useful for detecting services that are running on a host.

script_scan.title: Script Scan
script_scan.description: This is a list of nmap and crowler-scanner scripts to run. This is particularly important when a user wants to do vulnerability scanning.

excluded_hosts.title: Excluded Hosts
excluded_hosts.description: This is a list of hosts to exclude from the scan. The CROWler may encounter such hosts during its crawling activities, so this field makes it easy to define a list of hosts that it should always avoid scanning.

timing_template.title: Timing Template
timing_template.description: This allows the user to set the timing template for the scan. The timing template is a string that is passed to nmap to set the timing of the scan. DO not specify values using Tx, where x is a number. Instead, use just the number, e.g., '3'.

host_timeout.title: Host Timeout
host_timeout.description: This is the timeout for the scan. It is the maximum amount of time that the CROWler will wait for a host to respond to a scan.

min_rate.title: Minimum Rate
min_rate.description: This is the minimum rate at which the CROWler will scan hosts. It is the minimum number of packets that the CROWler will send to a host per second.

max_retries.title: Maximum Retries
max_retries.description: This is the maximum number of times that the CROWler will retry a scan on a host. If the CROWler is unable to scan a host after this number of retries, it will move on to the next host.

source_port.title: Source Port
source_port.description: This is the source port that the CROWler will use for scanning. It is the port that the CROWler will use to send packets to hosts.

interface.title: Interface
interface.description: This is the interface that the CROWler will use for scanning. It is the network interface that the CROWler will use to send packets to hosts. Use this option with a port that is behind a VPN or a proxy for better results.

spoof_ip.title: Spoof IP
spoof_ip.description: This is the IP address that the CROWler will use to spoof its identity. It is the IP address that the CROWler will use to send packets to hosts. Use this option with a port that is behind a VPN or a proxy for better results.

randomize_hosts.title: Randomize Hosts List
randomize_hosts.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to randomize the order in which it scans hosts. This is useful for avoiding detection by intrusion detection systems.

data_length.title: Data Length
data_length.description: This is the length of the data that the CROWler will send to hosts. It is the length of the data that the CROWler will use to send packets to hosts. Use this option with a port that is behind a VPN or a proxy for better results.

delay.title: Delay
delay.description: This is the delay between packets that the CROWler will use for scanning. It is the delay between packets that the CROWler will use to send packets to hosts. Use this option with a port that is behind a VPN or a proxy for better results. For the delay you can also use the CROWler exprterpreter to generate delay values at runtime, e.g., 'random(1, 3)' or 'random(random(1,3), random(5,8))'.

mtu_discovery.title: MTU Discovery
mtu_discovery.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to use MTU discovery when scanning hosts. This is useful for avoiding detection by intrusion detection systems.

scan_flags.title: Scan Flags
scan_flags.description: This is the flags that the CROWler will use for scanning. It is the flags that the CROWler will use to send packets to hosts. Use this option with a port that is behind a VPN or a proxy for better results.

ip_fragment.title: IP Fragment
ip_fragment.description: This is a flag that tells the CROWler to fragment IP packets. This is useful for avoiding detection by intrusion detection systems.

min_port_number.title: Minimum Port Number
min_port_number.description: This is the minimum port number to scan (default is 1).

max_port_number.title: Maximum Port Number
max_port_number.description: This is the maximum port number to scan (default is 9000).

max_parallelism.title: Maximum Parallelism
max_parallelism.description: This is the maximum number of parallelism used to provide scans for a single target. Multiple targets are ALWAYS scanned in parallel.

dns_servers.title: DNS Servers
dns_servers.description: This is a list of custom DNS servers.

proxies.title: Proxies
proxies.description: List of Proxies to use to perform a scan.

rulesets_schema_path.title: CROWler Ruleset JSON Schema location Configuration
rulesets_schema_path.description: This is the path to the rulesets schema. It is the path to the schema that the CROWler will use to validate the rulesets.

rulesets.title: CROWler Rulesets locations Configuration
rulesets.description: This is the rulesets load configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler where and how to load all the Rulesets we want to use to crawl, interact, scrape info and detect stuff on the provided Sources to crawl.

path.title: CROWler Rulesets Path
path.description: This is the path that the CROWler will use to fetch the ruleset. You can use wildcard to fetch multiple rulesets. for example './rules/*.yaml'.

host.title: CROWler Rulesets Host
host.description: This is the host that the CROWler will use to fetch the ruleset.

port.title: CROWler Rulesets Host Port
port.description: This is the port that the CROWler will use to fetch the ruleset.

region.title: CROWler Rulesets Host Region
region.description: This is the region that the CROWler will use to fetch the ruleset (for example, if you're hosting your ruleset on an AWS S3 bucket).

token.title: CROWler Rulesets Host access Token
token.description: This is the token that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to download the ruleset.

secret.title: CROWler Rulesets Host access Secret
secret.description: This is the secret that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to download the ruleset.

timeout.title: CROWler Rulesets Host Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout in seconds for the CROWler to fetch the ruleset.

type.title: CROWler Rulesets Host Type
type.description: This is the type of the distribution server that the CROWler will use to fetch the ruleset. For example, s3, http or local. (local is default)

sslmode.title: CROWler Rulesets Host SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to fetch the ruleset. Use 'enable' to force https over http.

refresh.title: CROWler Rulesets Automatic Refresh Interval
refresh.description: This is the refresh interval in seconds for the CROWler to fetch the ruleset (refresh it).

agents.title: CROWler Agents Configuration and locations
agents.description: This is the CROWler Agents configuration section. The Agents are used to process Data, Events and more. They are used to extend the CROWler's capabilities, without coding. Agents can be AI based or simple sets of actions, plugins and/or both. Each Agent is defined using YAML or JSON files.

global_parameters.title: CROWler Agents Global Parameters
global_parameters.description: This is the global parameters that the CROWler will pass to each agent in this batch load.

path.title: CROWler Agents load paths
path.description: This is the path that the CROWler will use to fetch the yaml or json file that defines one or more agents. You can use wildcard to fetch multiple files. for example './agents/*.yaml'.

host.title: CROWler Agents Host
host.description: This is the host that the CROWler will use to fetch the agents.

port.title: CROWler Agents Host Port
port.description: This is the port that the CROWler will use to fetch the agents.

region.title: CROWler Agents Host Region
region.description: This is the region that the CROWler will use to fetch the agents (for example, if you're hosting your agents on an AWS S3 bucket).

token.title: CROWler Agents Host access Token
token.description: This is the token that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to download the agents.

secret.title: CROWler Agents Host access Secret
secret.description: This is the secret that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to download the agents.

timeout.title: CROWler Agents Host Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout in seconds for the CROWler to fetch the agents.

agents_timeout.title: CROWler Agents Timeout
agents_timeout.description: This is the timeout in seconds for the CROWler to execute an agent.

plugins_timeout.title: CROWler Agents Plugins Timeout
plugins_timeout.description: This is the timeout in seconds for the CROWler to execute a plugin.

type.title: CROWler Agents Host Type
type.description: This is the type of the distribution server that the CROWler will use to fetch the agents. For example, s3, http or local. (local is default)

sslmode.title: CROWler Agents Host SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to fetch the agents. Use 'enable' to force https over http.

refresh.title: CROWler Agents Automatic Refresh Interval
refresh.description: This is the refresh interval in seconds for the CROWler to fetch the agents (refresh them).

plugins.title: CROWler Plugins locations Configuration
plugins.description: This is the Plugins configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine which plugins we want to use and provide the path to the plugins. Plugins are used to extend the CROWler's capabilities, for example, to detect phishing URLs, detect malware, detect network vulnerabilities, etc.

global_parameters.title: CROWler Plugins Global Parameters
global_parameters.description: This is the global parameters that the CROWler will pass to each plugin in this batch load.

timeout.title: CROWler Plugin Execution Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout in seconds for the CROWler to execute a plugin.

plugins_timeout.title: CROWler Plugins Execution Timeout
plugins_timeout.description: This is the timeout in seconds for the CROWler to execute a plugin.

locations.title: CROWler Plugins Locations List
locations.description: This is the list of locations from where the CROWler will load and register all available plugins.

path.title: CROWler Plugins location Path
path.description: This is the path to the plugin.

items.description: This is a list of paths from where the CROWler will search for plugins to load.

host.title: CROWler Plugins location Host
host.description: This is the host that the CROWler will use to fetch the plugin.

port.title: CROWler Plugins location Host Port
port.description: This is the port that the CROWler will use to fetch the plugin.

region.title: CROWler Plugins location Host Region
region.description: This is the region that the CROWler will use to fetch the plugin (for example, if you're hosting your plugin on an AWS S3 bucket).

token.title: CROWler Plugins location Host access Token
token.description: This is the token that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to download the plugin.

secret.title: CROWler Plugins location Host access Secret
secret.description: This is the secret that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to download the plugin.

timeout.title: CROWler Plugins location Host Timeout
timeout.description: This is the timeout in seconds for the CROWler to fetch the plugin.

type.title: CROWler Plugins location Host Type
type.description: This is the type of the distribution server that the CROWler will use to fetch the plugin. For example, s3, http or local. (local is default)

sslmode.title: CROWler Plugins location Host SSL Mode
sslmode.description: This is the sslmode that the CROWler will use to connect to the distribution server to fetch the plugin. Use 'enable' to force https over http.

refresh.title: CROWler Plugins location Automatic Refresh Interval
refresh.description: This is the refresh interval in seconds for the CROWler to fetch the plugin (refresh it). Zero means no refresh.

external_detection.title: CROWler External Detection Services Configuration
external_detection.description: This is the External Detection configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine which external detection services we want to use and provide credentials to access them. External detection services are provided by VirusTotal, URLHaus, PhishTank, GoogleSafeBrowsing, AbuseIPDB, OpenPhish, Cuckoo, HybridAnalysis, CiscoUmbrella, AlienVault, IPVoid, Shodan, Censys, SSLLabs. They can be accessed using the CROWler's Detection Rules.

abuse_ipdb.title: AbuseIPDB Configuration
abuse_ipdb.description: This is the AbuseIPDB configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine how to connect to AbuseIPDB and use its services. AbuseIPDB will be accessed through CROWler's Detection Rules.

url_haus.description: This is the URLHaus configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine how to connect to URLHaus and use its services. URLHaus will be accessed through CROWler's Detection Rules.

virus_total.title: VirusTotal Configuration
virus_total.description: This is the VirusTotal configuration section, it is used to tell the CROWler's Engine how to connect to VirusTotal and use its services. VirusTotal will be accessed through CROWler's Detection Rules.

api_key.title: VirusTotal API Key
api_key.description: This is the API key that the CROWler will use to connect to VirusTotal.

os.title: CROWler (internal) Platform OS Configuration
os.description: This is the operating system that the CROWler will use to run. For example, linux, windows or macos. This field is set automatically by the CROWler itself, so no need to set it manually.

debug_level.title: CROWler Debug Level Configuration
debug_level.description: This is the debug level for the CROWler. It is the level of debugging that the CROWler will use to log messages. The higher the level, the more messages will be logged. Don't set or use 0 for NO debug messages.

oneOf.title: Remote Configuration Mode
oneOf.description: Configuration where the 'remote' field must be provided. In this case, the local configuration sections like 'database', 'crawler', and others should not be populated.

oneOf.title: Local Configuration Mode
oneOf.description: Configuration where the 'database', 'crawler', 'api', 'selenium', and 'network_info' fields must be provided. In this case, the 'remote' field should not be populated.
